content: Choose your chalk. Thick sidewalk chalk works the best for this. You can also use regular chalk, like the kind teachers use on chalkboards. If you want something more vibrant, you could try soft chalk pastels ( not the oil kind). This method creates a washable sidewalk chalk. It will not work on furniture or DIY chalkboards. Grind chalk into a powder. The easiest way to do this would be with a food grater. [1] If you don't have any graters on hand, place the chalk into a plastic bag, then smash it with a hammer until it is fine and powdery. If you are using a food grater, make sure it's not one that you actually cook with. Use a separate one. Mix the chalk with some water. Pour the powdered chalk into a plastic container. Stir in up to ½ cup (120 milliliters) of water. [2] If you used regular chalk or a chalk pastel, try 1/4 to 1/3 cup (60 to cc milliliters) instead. Plastic food containers and clean, empty yogurt containers work great for this. If the paint is too thin, add some more chalk. If the paint is too thick, add in a little bit more water. Use the paint. Dip a paintbrush into the paint, then draw designs on the sidewalk or driveway. Let the paint dry, then marvel in your artwork. To clean up the sidewalk or driveway, simply wash it down with water. Place 6 tablespoons (45 grams) of cornstarch into a bowl. This recipe is great for making washable sidewalk paint. [3] It is not recommended for furniture or DIY chalkboards. If you can't find cornstarch, look for cornflour instead (but not cornmeal). Slowly stir in some cold water into the cornstarch. You will need a little less than ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of water. Stir the two together with a whisk until the cornstarch dissolves. Do not over-mix, however, or the cornstarch will start to turn solid. If you can drizzle the cornstarch water from your whisk, you're ready for the next step. [4] Stir in some food coloring. You can use either the liquid kind or the gel kind. You can also use liquid watercolor instead. How much you add is completely up to you. The more you add, the darker, deeper the color will be. Start with a few drops, and see how you like it. [5] Use the paint. Dip a paintbrush into the paint, then paint designs onto your sidewalk or driveway. Let it dry and admire your work. When you are done, simply wash it away with water. Although this paint is washable, it can stain light surfaces. Be careful! Have your surface ready to paint. This recipe dries quickly; you won't be able to store the paint for later use. Have your work surface covered and your brushes laid out. If the surface you are going to paint needs to be sanded or cleaned, do this now. [6] This recipe is perfect for making DIY chalkboards. You can use this recipe to paint furniture as well. Mix some grout with water. Place 2 tablespoons (30 grams) of non-sanded grout into a mixing container. Stir in 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of cool water. You want the consistency to be smooth. [7] The container needs to be large enough to hold at least 1 cup (240 milliliters). Stir some paint into the grout mixture. Pour 1 cup (240 milliliters) of latex or acrylic paint into the grout mixture. [8] Stir it in well until the consistency is smooth. You will need to stir for a good 5 minutes or so. [9] Apply two coats of paint. Use a paintbrush or a foam brush to apply your first coat of paint. Let it dry for a few hours, then apply a second one. [10] You can use acrylic or latex paint. [11] If you are painting a DIY chalkboard, consider using dark green or black paint. Allow the paint to cure for 3 days. This is very important. If you use your surface too soon, the paint may come off or turn gummy. [12] Condition the surface if you are using it as a chalkboard. If you plan on using your surface as an actual chalkboard, you should prime it. To prime the chalkboard, simply coat the entire surface with a piece of chalk, then wipe it off with a dry cloth. [13] Skip this step if you painted a piece of furniture that you don't plan writing on. Make a basic recipe with Plaster of Paris. Mix together 2½ tablespoons (31 grams) of Plaster of Paris and 1½ tablespoons (22.5 milliliters) of cool water. Stir in 1 cup (240 milliliters) of latex paint. [14] Make distress-able paint with calcium carbonate. Combine 2 tablespoons (25 grams) of calcium carbonate with 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of water. Stir this into 1 cup (240 milliliters) of latex paint. [15] This paint works well in paint sprayers. This paint is great for painting furniture and then distressing it with sandpaper. You can find calcium carbonate powder in health food stores and online. [16] Make durable paint with both calcium carbonate and Plaster of Paris. Mix together 2 tablespoons (25 grams) of calcium carbonate powder, 2 tablespoons (25 grams) of Plaster of Paris, and 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of cool water. Add 2 cups (475 milliliters) of latex paint and stir well. [17] This paint durable. It does not scratch or distress easily. Use baking soda with care. Baking soda is more readily available than calcium carbonate and Plaster of Paris. The resulting finish is very grainy, however. If the texture doesn't bother you, you can prepare baking soda chalk paint by stirring ⅓ cup (60 grams) of baking soda into ⅔ cups (160 milliliters) of paint. [18] If the paint is too thick, try dissolving ½ cup (90 grams) of baking soda in 3 tablespoons (45 milliliters) of water, then adding it to 1 cup (240 milliliters) of latex paint. [19]

<p>There are two types of chalk paint: the washable kind that you can use on the sidewalk and the permanent kind that you can use on furniture. To make the washable kind of paint, you will need to use chalk or cornstarch as a base. To make the permanent kind, you will need something more durable such as Plaster of Paris. Making your own paint takes more effort than running to the store and buying some, but it can save you lots of money!</p>

<a class="anchor" name="Making_Simple_Washable_Paint_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Making_Simple_Washable_Paint">Making Simple Washable Paint</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_7e799fc8be" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7e799fc8be')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose your chalk.</b> Thick sidewalk chalk works the best for this. You can also use regular chalk, like the kind teachers use on chalkboards. If you want something more vibrant, you could try soft chalk pastels (<i>not</i> the oil kind).

<ul>
<li>This method creates a washable sidewalk chalk. It will not work on furniture or DIY chalkboards.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-2-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-2-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_febacc1e05" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_febacc1e05')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Grind chalk into a powder.</b> The easiest way to do this would be with a food grater.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup> If you don't have any graters on hand, place the chalk into a plastic bag, then smash it with a hammer until it is fine and powdery.

<ul>
<li>If you are using a food grater, make sure it's not one that you actually cook with. Use a separate one.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_9b57fdf65f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9b57fdf65f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Mix the chalk with some water.</b> Pour the powdered chalk into a plastic container. Stir in up to ½ cup (120 milliliters) of water.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup> If you used regular chalk or a chalk pastel, try 1/4 to 1/3 cup (60 to cc milliliters) instead.

<ul>
<li>Plastic food containers and clean, empty yogurt containers work great for this.</li>
<li>If the paint is too thin, add some more chalk. If the paint is too thick, add in a little bit more water.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_36d622ed48" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_36d622ed48')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use the paint.</b> Dip a paintbrush into the paint, then draw designs on the sidewalk or driveway. Let the paint dry, then marvel in your artwork. To clean up the sidewalk or driveway, simply wash it down with water.

</div>

</li>
</ol>

<a class="anchor" name="Making_Washable_Paint_with_Cornstarch_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Making_Washable_Paint_with_Cornstarch">Making Washable Paint with Cornstarch</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_1cd507983d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1cd507983d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Place 6 tablespoons (45 grams) of cornstarch into a bowl.</b> This recipe is great for making washable sidewalk paint.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup> It is not recommended for furniture or DIY chalkboards.

<ul>
<li>If you can't find cornstarch, look for cornflour instead (but <i>not</i> cornmeal).</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_ebec47ca9e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ebec47ca9e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Slowly stir in some cold water into the cornstarch.</b> You will need a little less than ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of water. Stir the two together with a whisk until the cornstarch dissolves. Do not over-mix, however, or the cornstarch will start to turn solid. If you can drizzle the cornstarch water from your whisk, you're ready for the next step.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-7.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-7.jpg" height="485" id="img_e8616a2372" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e8616a2372')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-7.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Stir in some food coloring.</b> You can use either the liquid kind or the gel kind. You can also use liquid watercolor instead. How much you add is completely up to you. The more you add, the darker, deeper the color will be. Start with a few drops, and see how you like it.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-8.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-8.jpg" height="485" id="img_f592952efb" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f592952efb')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-8.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use the paint.</b> Dip a paintbrush into the paint, then paint designs onto your sidewalk or driveway. Let it dry and admire your work. When you are done, simply wash it away with water.

<ul>
<li>Although this paint is washable, it can stain light surfaces. Be careful!</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Making_Chalkboard_Paint_with_Grout_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Making_Chalkboard_Paint_with_Grout">Making Chalkboard Paint with Grout</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-9.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-9.jpg" height="485" id="img_c35201c2e2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c35201c2e2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-9.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Have your surface ready to paint.</b> This recipe dries quickly; you won't be able to store the paint for later use. Have your work surface covered and your brushes laid out. If the surface you are going to paint needs to be sanded or cleaned, do this now.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>This recipe is perfect for making DIY chalkboards.</li>
<li>You can use this recipe to paint furniture as well.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-10.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-10.jpg" height="485" id="img_f5d58f6b6a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f5d58f6b6a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-10.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Mix some grout with water.</b> Place 2 tablespoons (30 grams) of non-sanded grout into a mixing container. Stir in 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of cool water. You want the consistency to be smooth.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>The container needs to be large enough to hold at least 1 cup (240 milliliters).</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-11.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-11.jpg" height="485" id="img_08e39bac94" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_08e39bac94')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-11.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Stir some paint into the grout mixture.</b> Pour 1 cup (240 milliliters) of latex or acrylic paint into the grout mixture.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Stir it in well until the consistency is smooth. You will need to stir for a good 5 minutes or so.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-12.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-12.jpg" height="485" id="img_2e309dead4" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2e309dead4')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-12.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Apply two coats of paint.</b> Use a paintbrush or a foam brush to apply your first coat of paint. Let it dry for a few hours, then apply a second one.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup> You can use acrylic or latex paint.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you are painting a DIY chalkboard, consider using dark green or black paint.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-13.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-13.jpg" height="485" id="img_eddddf4cf6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_eddddf4cf6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Chalk Paint Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-13.jpg/aid97313-v4-728px-Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Allow the paint to cure for 3 days.</b> This is very important. If you use your surface too soon, the paint may come off or turn gummy.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=97313" href="#/Image:Make-Chalk-Paint-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">

<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_1"></a><div class="step">

<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_2"></a><div class="step">

<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_3"></a><div class="step">

<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_4"></a><div class="step">

title: How to Make Chalk Paint
content_html:
Choose your chalk. Thick sidewalk chalk works the best for this. You can also use regular chalk, like the kind teachers use on chalkboards. If you want something more vibrant, you could try soft chalk pastels (not the oil kind).
  • This method creates a washable sidewalk chalk. It will not work on furniture or DIY chalkboards.
Grind chalk into a powder. The easiest way to do this would be with a food grater.[1] If you don't have any graters on hand, place the chalk into a plastic bag, then smash it with a hammer until it is fine and powdery.
  • If you are using a food grater, make sure it's not one that you actually cook with. Use a separate one.
Mix the chalk with some water. Pour the powdered chalk into a plastic container. Stir in up to ½ cup (120 milliliters) of water.[2] If you used regular chalk or a chalk pastel, try 1/4 to 1/3 cup (60 to cc milliliters) instead.
  • Plastic food containers and clean, empty yogurt containers work great for this.
  • If the paint is too thin, add some more chalk. If the paint is too thick, add in a little bit more water.
Use the paint. Dip a paintbrush into the paint, then draw designs on the sidewalk or driveway. Let the paint dry, then marvel in your artwork. To clean up the sidewalk or driveway, simply wash it down with water.
Place 6 tablespoons (45 grams) of cornstarch into a bowl. This recipe is great for making washable sidewalk paint.[3] It is not recommended for furniture or DIY chalkboards.
  • If you can't find cornstarch, look for cornflour instead (but not cornmeal).
Slowly stir in some cold water into the cornstarch. You will need a little less than ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of water. Stir the two together with a whisk until the cornstarch dissolves. Do not over-mix, however, or the cornstarch will start to turn solid. If you can drizzle the cornstarch water from your whisk, you're ready for the next step.[4]
Stir in some food coloring. You can use either the liquid kind or the gel kind. You can also use liquid watercolor instead. How much you add is completely up to you. The more you add, the darker, deeper the color will be. Start with a few drops, and see how you like it.[5]
Use the paint. Dip a paintbrush into the paint, then paint designs onto your sidewalk or driveway. Let it dry and admire your work. When you are done, simply wash it away with water.
  • Although this paint is washable, it can stain light surfaces. Be careful!
Have your surface ready to paint. This recipe dries quickly; you won't be able to store the paint for later use. Have your work surface covered and your brushes laid out. If the surface you are going to paint needs to be sanded or cleaned, do this now.[6]
  • This recipe is perfect for making DIY chalkboards.
  • You can use this recipe to paint furniture as well.
Mix some grout with water. Place 2 tablespoons (30 grams) of non-sanded grout into a mixing container. Stir in 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of cool water. You want the consistency to be smooth.[7]
  • The container needs to be large enough to hold at least 1 cup (240 milliliters).
Stir some paint into the grout mixture. Pour 1 cup (240 milliliters) of latex or acrylic paint into the grout mixture.[8] Stir it in well until the consistency is smooth. You will need to stir for a good 5 minutes or so.[9]
Apply two coats of paint. Use a paintbrush or a foam brush to apply your first coat of paint. Let it dry for a few hours, then apply a second one.[10] You can use acrylic or latex paint.[11]
  • If you are painting a DIY chalkboard, consider using dark green or black paint.
Allow the paint to cure for 3 days. This is very important. If you use your surface too soon, the paint may come off or turn gummy.[12]
Condition the surface if you are using it as a chalkboard. If you plan on using your surface as an actual chalkboard, you should prime it. To prime the chalkboard, simply coat the entire surface with a piece of chalk, then wipe it off with a dry cloth.[13]
  • Skip this step if you painted a piece of furniture that you don't plan writing on.
Make a basic recipe with Plaster of Paris. Mix together 2½ tablespoons (31 grams) of Plaster of Paris and 1½ tablespoons (22.5 milliliters) of cool water. Stir in 1 cup (240 milliliters) of latex paint.[14]
Make distress-able paint with calcium carbonate. Combine 2 tablespoons (25 grams) of calcium carbonate with 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of water. Stir this into 1 cup (240 milliliters) of latex paint.[15]
  • This paint works well in paint sprayers.
  • This paint is great for painting furniture and then distressing it with sandpaper.
  • You can find calcium carbonate powder in health food stores and online.[16]
Make durable paint with both calcium carbonate and Plaster of Paris. Mix together 2 tablespoons (25 grams) of calcium carbonate powder, 2 tablespoons (25 grams) of Plaster of Paris, and 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of cool water. Add 2 cups (475 milliliters) of latex paint and stir well.[17]
  • This paint durable. It does not scratch or distress easily.
Use baking soda with care. Baking soda is more readily available than calcium carbonate and Plaster of Paris. The resulting finish is very grainy, however. If the texture doesn't bother you, you can prepare baking soda chalk paint by stirring ⅓ cup (60 grams) of baking soda into ⅔ cups (160 milliliters) of paint.[18]
  • If the paint is too thick, try dissolving ½ cup (90 grams) of baking soda in 3 tablespoons (45 milliliters) of water, then adding it to 1 cup (240 milliliters) of latex paint.[19]
